importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Mr. Vedam was sentenced to a two-and-a-half to five-year drug sentence in 1984, which was served simultaneously with his life sentence for murder. This date marks a key point in the timeline of his incarceration and legal history.
A deportation order was issued in 1988 based on Mr. Vedam's murder and drug convictions, which remained in effect even after his exoneration of the murder charge.

The article was published on this date, marking the current status of the case: Mr. Vedam is now facing deportation despite being exonerated of the murder charge and having served over 40 years in prison.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from the 1970s to 1984 encompasses the time when Mr. Vedam was convicted, imprisoned, and began serving overlapping sentences. It reflects the era of his wrongful imprisonment and the legal system’s failure to recognize his innocence.

The recent years (2024–2025) saw the emergence of new evidence exonerating Mr. Vedam and the subsequent legal battle over his deportation, highlighting a current human rights concern in immigration policy.

keyTakeAways: Subramanyam 'Subu' Vedam was wrongfully imprisoned for over 40 years for a murder he did not commit.
New evidence exonerated Vedam of the murder of Tom Kinser, a 19-year-old college student, with no physical evidence linking him to the crime.
Despite being cleared of the murder charge, Vedam is still subject to a 1988 deportation order based on his drug conviction.
ICE has detained Vedam and intends to deport him to India, despite having no familial or social ties there and having lived in the U.S. since infancy.
Vedam’s family and legal team argue that his decades of good behavior, community service, and academic achievements should be considered in his immigration case.
The case raises broader concerns about how immigration enforcement agencies apply historical convictions, especially when those convictions are based on false or unsubstantiated charges.
The family and advocates believe that deporting Vedam would be a second wrong — one that erases the possibility of a meaningful reintegration into family and society.
Vedam, a legal permanent resident, had his citizenship application accepted before arrest, and both parents were U.S. citizens.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Subramanyam 'Subu' Vedam, a legal permanent resident of the United States, was wrongfully imprisoned for over 40 years for the murder of his former roommate Tom Kinser, a 19-year-old college student, despite having no physical evidence linking him to the crime. After new evidence exonerated him and a Pennsylvania district attorney decided not to pursue a new trial, Vedam was finally released from prison. However, before he could reunite with his family, he was detained by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), which seeks to deport him to India — a country he has not lived in since infancy. His family and legal team argue that the deportation is unjust, given his decades of good behavior, community service, and strong ties to the U.S., and that the 1988 deportation order was based on a drug conviction that remains valid, even after the murder charge was dismissed. The case raises serious questions about how immigration enforcement agencies apply historical convictions, especially when those convictions are based on false or unsubstantiated charges, and highlights the need for reform in systems that fail to recognize wrongful convictions and protect individuals with strong ties to the U.S.
title: Wrongfully imprisoned for more than 40 years, Pennsylvania man now faces deportation by ICE
